image.altText: a pregnant woman lying on a couch holding her belly

props.synopsis: South Australia's upper house has narrowly voted down a proposal to amend abortion laws so that people who want to terminate their pregnancy after 28 weeks would be required to deliver their baby alive.

title.children: Late-term abortion bill defeated in SA's upper house

image.altText: A waterway closed over by sand.

props.synopsis: A freak storm brought nearly 100,000 cubic metres of sand into the entrance of Cape Jaffa's marina, but the South Australian government says it can't help the local council.

title.children: Popular marina closed off by enough sand to fill nearly 40 Olympic pools

image.altText: A rocket flies over farmland

props.synopsis: A Canadian company has signed a deal to test its rocket in South Australia next year. If successful, it will be the first time a rocket reaches space from the remote Koonibba base.

title.children: Tiny South Australian town to host first rocket launch to space

image.altText: Storm clouds brewing at night, with shades of blue and green, over green pastures

props.synopsis: A spell of wild weather is on the cards for everywhere from Queensland to Tasmania, with thunderstorms forecast to sweep across Australia's east over the next 48 hours.

title.children: Wild weather predicted across Australia's south-east over next 48 hours

image.altText: A man wearing a green jacket and hat holding tomatoes.

props.synopsis: Tomato growers placed into quarantine after the discovery of the tomato brown rugose virus say authorities should have been better prepared for the arrival of the virus.

title.children: 'Devastated': Tens of millions of dollars in losses smash Australian tomato farmers

image.altText: Hainsworth

props.synopsis: A five-hour police interview with accused serial killer Steven Hainsworth reveals his DNA was found at the scene of his aunt's murder and that he pawned some of her belongings within hours of her death.

title.children: Police grill alleged triple murderer in recorded interview

image.altText: Two oval containers with white pouches and golden pouches on a background of yellow and orange graphic.

props.synopsis: Teens say an illegal nicotine product is easy to procure, leaving experts calling for better enforcement.

title.children: Nicotine pouches are illegal in Australia, so how are young people getting hold of them?

image.altText: Riverlea

props.synopsis: Part of the Riverlea development was brought to a halt after Indigenous remains were found at the $3 billion housing estate last year. Now the SA government has given developers the go ahead, with conditions, in what one senior Kaurna woman has described as "bittersweet".

title.children: Aboriginal remains were found at this housing development. Now, construction can resume

image.altText: A politician speaking to the media.

props.synopsis: David Speirs, who held the role of SA opposition leader for almost two-and-a-half years, formally quits parliament 10 days after he revealed police had arrested him on suspicion of drug offences.

title.children: Former Liberal leader officially quits SA parliament days after police said he was facing drug charges

image.altText: Selfie of a man wearing a cap and safety gear inside a helicopter

props.synopsis: Being given just six months to live came as a shock to Craig Pankhurst because he assumed not hearing from the doctor about his most recent prostate-specific antigen test was a good thing. But it wasn't.

title.children: It shouldn't have taken a 'crook tooth' for Craig to learn he had life-threatening prostate cancer

image.altText: M1A1 Abrams tank

props.synopsis: The announcement was welcomed by Ukraine's ambassador to Australia, Vasyl Myroshnychenko.

title.children: Ukraine to receive aging Abrams tanks in latest Australian military aid package

image.altText: A local resident and a rescuer stand on debris of a building.

props.synopsis: The Ukrainian president tells politicians his plan contains five main points that rely on Kyiv's allies, including an unconditional invitation to join NATO and specific weapons support.

title.children: Zelenskyy unveils victory plan as Russia reports capture of two Ukrainian villages

image.altText: Liam Hooper sits at a cafe table on a city street.

props.synopsis: Staring at a third recession in just two years, Kiwis are moving across the ditch to Australia in substantial numbers, seeking a sunnier economic climate.

title.children: New Zealand's economic woes lure thousands of Kiwis to Australia

image.altText: a grandmother, daughter and grandaughter on a horse in an equestrian competition.

props.synopsis: Country shows are about more than rides and show bags. Many say they are a lifeline for farmers and regional communities doing it tough.

title.children: What agricultural shows mean to farming communities during tough seasons

image.altText: A grey and white little fluffy Greater gliders on a gum tree  branch looking ahead with big round eyes and a long fluffy tail.

props.synopsis: Logging is set to continue in areas where hundreds of endangered gliders have been sighted, despite conservationists warning the government regulator of their presence.

title.children: Logging set to continue in areas where hundreds of endangered gliders are present

image.altText: The 23andMe logo seen on a smartphone.

props.synopsis: Eight years ago, in what now seems like an act of reckless naivety, I bought my brother a 23andMe at-home DNA-test birthday present. Now the struggling company may sell its treasure trove of genetic data.

title.children: Eight years ago, my brother gave his DNA to 23andMe. We can't take it back — and it may soon get sold

image.altText: Troy Bell walks outside a court building holding a note pad.

props.synopsis: Independent Mount Gambier MP Troy Bell says he will fight the jury's guilty verdicts and hopes to clear his name while continuing to represent his community.

title.children: MP found guilty of fraud offences vows to clear his name

image.altText: An older couple smile, standing in a kitchen holding kitchen utensils over a pot full of food.

props.synopsis: The latest Foodbank Hunger Report has found 3.4 million households across Australia are experiencing food insecurity, with low income earners having to skip meals or eat less because they cannot afford enough food.

title.children: These pensioners feed vulnerable families. They're seeing a disturbing trend that's been echoed in a new hunger report

image.altText: Justice Gregory Geason looks off camera.

props.synopsis: Justice Gregory Geason has been on leave with pay for almost a year while he faced allegations of family violence, but the Tasmanian government appears to have no mechanism to suspend or remove him, even after his guilty verdict.

title.children: Judge guilty of causing concussion and bruising to a woman, but will remain on a $500,000 salary

image.altText: A streak of white among a purple sky above green grass at night

props.synopsis: The phenomenon is not well understood, and an astrophysicist says it is hard to predict when and where Steve will appear next.

title.children: Photographers looking for Aurora Australis capture mysterious phenomenon Steve instead

image.altText: A ni-Vanuatu man poses with his daughter, who is wearing a bright pink dress

props.synopsis: A former striker for Vanuatu's national youth soccer team drowned in a dam while on the job in Australia. He's one of at least 84 Pacific seasonal workers who have died here since 2020.

title.children: At least 84 Pacific seasonal workers have died in four years. Their families are often left empty-handed

image.altText: a female snorkeller taking a photo of a turtle underwater

props.synopsis: The artificial intelligence used for passport facial scanning is now helping Australian conservationists track elusive sea turtles.

title.children: Conservationists keep tabs on sea turtles with the same face scanning tech used in airports

image.altText: The clasped feet of a ten-month-old baby boy on a blue rug.

props.synopsis: The national birth rate has hit a record low and is now at a critical level, with economic consequences for the future.

title.children: Australia's 'perilously low' birth rate approaches point of no return

image.altText: Mackenzie Eardley hugs teammates

props.synopsis: Hawthorn has gone from being a team unable to make use of the ball to one of the AFLW's most exciting teams. Here's how the Hawks did it.

title.children: How the Hawks learned to score

image.altText: Prince Charles and Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, wave farewell before boarding a plane.

props.synopsis: King Charles is heading to Australia for his first royal visit since becoming king. Here's where you might catch a glimpse of royalty.

title.children: Here's where you can catch a glimpse of Charles and Camilla in Australia

image.altText: A cloud of grey dusty smoke rises in the middle of a tightly packed city of apartments

props.synopsis: A barrage of Israeli air strikes hit towns across southern Lebanon and Beirut's southern suburbs. Meanwhile, the Israeli prime minister dismisses calls for a ceasefire.

title.children: Mayor of Lebanese town killed in Israeli strikes as Netanyahu rejects calls for ceasefire

image.altText: An aerial shot of the Geelong Waterfront.

props.synopsis: Police are investigating the alleged theft of possibly more than $100,000 from G21 Geelong Region Alliance. The advocacy group is primarily funded by five local councils between Geelong and Colac Otway Shire.

title.children: 'This is ratepayer money': Police probe years-long theft from major advocacy group

image.altText: What appears to be the feet of a male, following someone in high heels in a dark environment with shadows.

props.synopsis: A Personal Safety Survey, released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, has found an estimated 2.7 million Australians have been stalked, with women more likely to be followed by a man they know.

title.children: One in five Australian women have been stalked, according to new data

image.altText: Dozens of army recruits in green uniforms crowd around a desk where some people are signing white forms

props.synopsis: State media claims more than a million people have signed up to North Korea's army, as tensions continue to simmer between Pyongyang and South Korea.

title.children: 'Wiped off the map': North Korea claims more than a million new recruits have signed up to its army amid tensions with South Korea

image.altText: Dozens of people put their hands in the air at a concert.

props.synopsis: Hidden fees and practices like dynamic pricing — which sees ticket prices go up as an event becomes more popular — have outraged consumers.

title.children: Concert ticket dynamic pricing, hotel and gym hidden fees, face government ban

image.altText: a woman giving the finger at a man as he walks away

props.synopsis: Elizabeth Lee made the gesture towards a journalist at a press conference after the ACT Property Council's leaders' debate on Wednesday.

title.children: Canberra Liberals leader Elizabeth Lee makes rude gesture at journalist following tense press conference exchange

image.altText: Jerry Seinfeld smiling.

props.synopsis: US comedian Jerry Seinfeld walks back a claim he made earlier this year that there is a lack of quality television comedy because "people [are] worrying so much about offending other people".

title.children: US comedian Jerry Seinfeld retracts claim 'extreme left' has ruined TV comedy

image.altText: A close up of Donald Trump dancing at campaign event

props.synopsis: The US presidential candidate wrapped up his event ahead of schedule but remained on stage while nine songs played.

title.children: Donald Trump turns campaign event into impromptu musical session

image.altText: Five beers are held up as people cheers

props.synopsis: Prague has banned night-time pub crawls organised by travel agencies. Is this the end of the stag do?

title.children: World's thirstiest nation bans organised night-time pub crawls

image.altText: A seawall damaged in a storm.

props.synopsis: Roads and beaches on the tropical Cocos (Keeling) Islands in the Indian Ocean remain shut, but a rising tide and further high swells have officials worried that the worst is yet to come.

title.children: 'Absolute freak' swells topple seawalls, bury beaches on Australia's most remote territory
